questiontext.text:
Engineering Example: Velocity of a rocket

The upward velocity of a rocket, measured at 3 different times, is shown in the following table \[\begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Time}, t & \text{Velocity}, v \\ \text{(seconds)}& \text{(metres/second)} \\ \hline 5&106.8\\ \hline 8&177.2\\ \hline 12&279.2\\ \hline \end{array}\] The velocity over the time interval \(5\leq t\leq 12\) is approximated by a quadratic expression as \[v(t)=a_1t^2+a_2t+a_3\] Find the values of \(a_1, a_2\) and \(a_3\).

Solution

Substituting the values from the table into the quadratic equation for \(v(t)\) gives: \[\begin{array}{l} 106.8 & = & 25a_1 & + & 5a_2 & + & a_3 \\ 177.2 & = & 64a_1 & + & 8a_2 & + & a_3 \\ 279.2 & = & 144a_1 & + & 12a_2 & + & a_3 \\ \end{array} \qquad \text{or} \qquad \left[\begin{matrix} 25&5&1\\ 64&8&1\\ 144&12&1 \end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix} a_1\\a_2\\a_3 \end{matrix}\right]= \left[\begin{matrix} 106.8\\ 177.2\\ 279.2 \end{matrix}\right]\] Applying one of the methods youâ€™ve learned gives the solution as \[a_1=0.2905\qquad a_2=19.6905\qquad a_3=1.0857 \quad \text{to } 4 \text{ d.p}.\] As the original values were all experimental observations then the values of the unknowns are all approximations. The relation \(v(t)=0.2905t^2+19.6905t+1.0857\) can now be used to predict the approximate position of the rocket for any time within the interval \(5\leq t \leq 12\).
